qas.question: Why were decoy towns used in WW2

answers.text: decoy towns were constructed in Somerset in World War II to protect Bristol and other towns, at night

qas.question: What did the decoy towns mimic

answers.text: mimic the geometry of "blacked out" streets, railway lines, and Bristol Temple Meads railway station, to encourage bombers away from these targets
Shepperton Studios, based on aerial photographs of the city's railway marshalling yards. The decoys were fitted with dim red lights
The Chew Magna decoy town was hit by half-a-dozen bombs on 2 December 1940, and over a thousand incendiaries on 3 January 1941

qas.question: How many times was the Uphill decoy town bombed on 4 January 1942?
Who laid out Chew Magna decoy town?
How many dairy cows were killed when the Uphill decoy town was bombed?
Who created the Uphill decoy town?
Where did the Pathfinder night bombers usually take off from to bomb Somerset?

context: A number of <a0_0>decoy towns were constructed in Somerset in World War II to protect <b7_0>Bristol<b7_0/> and other towns, at night<a0_0/>. They were designed to <a1_0>mimic the geometry of "blacked out" streets, railway lines, and Bristol Temple Meads railway station, to encourage bombers away from these targets<a1_0/>. One, on the radio beam flight path to Bristol, was constructed on Beacon Batch. It was laid out by <a2_0><b5_0>Shepperton Studios<b5_0/>, based on aerial photographs of the city's railway marshalling yards. The decoys were fitted with dim red lights<a2_0/>, simulating activities like the stoking of steam locomotives. Burning bales of straw soaked in creosote were used to simulate the effects of incendiary bombs dropped by the first wave of Pathfinder night bombers; meanwhile, incendiary bombs dropped on the correct location were quickly smothered, wherever possible. Drums of oil were also ignited to simulate the effect of a blazing city or town, with the aim of fooling subsequent waves of bombers into dropping their bombs on the wrong location. <a3_0>The Chew Magna decoy town was hit by <b4_0><b6_0>half-a-dozen<b6_0/><b4_0/> bombs on 2 December 1940, and over a thousand incendiaries on 3 January 1941<a3_0/>. The following night the Uphill decoy town, protecting <b8_0>Weston-super-Mare's airfield<b8_0/>, was bombed; a herd of dairy cows was hit, killing some and severely injuring others.
